question.text: What share of global energy will come from renewable sources in 2050?

config.context: Current renewable share: ~15% (2024). Paris targets: 60-70% by 2050. Key uncertainties: policy ambition, battery/storage costs, grid infrastructure, fossil fuel phase-out pace, nuclear expansion.

uncertainties.name: Energy Transition Speed
uncertainties.description: The pace of renewable energy adoption drives massive infrastructure investment, job transitions, and energy cost changes that significantly impact GDP growth through capital allocation, labor market effects, and international competitiveness in energy-intensive industries.
uncertainties.low_state: Slow transition: Renewables reach only 35-40% of global energy by 2050, dominated by continued fossil fuel dependence with high stranded asset costs and delayed infrastructure modernization.
uncertainties.high_state: Rapid transition: Renewables achieve 70-80% of global energy by 2050, driving massive green infrastructure investment, energy cost reductions, and technological leadership advantages.
signals: By December 2027, global renewable energy investment exceeds $2 trillion annually, per IEA World Energy Investment report
By January 2029, at least 15 countries achieve >50% renewable electricity generation for full calendar year 2028, per national energy statistics
Before June 2030, Tesla or Chinese EV manufacturers achieve >20% global auto market share, per automotive industry sales data
By December 2028, green hydrogen production costs fall below $3/kg in at least 5 major markets, per BloombergNEF hydrogen price tracking
Before January 2031, fossil fuel companies write down >$500 billion in stranded assets cumulatively since 2025, per company SEC filings and annual reports

uncertainties.name: Climate Investment Returns
uncertainties.description: Whether climate adaptation and green technology investments generate positive economic returns versus becoming costly burdens determines GDP trajectories, as trillions in climate-related spending either boost productivity and competitiveness or drain resources without commensurate gains.
uncertainties.low_state: Poor returns: Climate investments yield low productivity gains, green technologies remain expensive, and adaptation costs drain resources without generating economic benefits, reducing overall GDP growth.
uncertainties.high_state: Strong returns: Climate technologies achieve breakthrough cost reductions, green infrastructure drives productivity gains, and early movers capture export advantages, boosting GDP through innovation and efficiency.
signals: By December 2028, solar and wind achieve grid parity (unsubsidized) in >20 major economies, per IRENA Global Energy Transformation report
Before January 2030, at least 5 climate adaptation projects demonstrate >15% annual ROI, per World Bank infrastructure project evaluations
By June 2029, green technology exports from leading countries (US, China, EU) exceed $500 billion annually, per WTO trade statistics
Before December 2030, battery storage costs fall below $50/kWh at utility scale, per BloombergNEF battery price survey
By January 2031, carbon pricing mechanisms cover >40% of global emissions with average price >$75/tonne CO2, per World Bank carbon pricing dashboard

signals.text: By December 2027, global renewable energy investment exceeds $2 trillion annually, per IEA World Energy Investment report
By January 2029, at least 15 countries achieve >50% renewable electricity generation for full calendar year 2028, per national energy statistics
Before June 2030, Tesla or Chinese EV manufacturers achieve >20% global auto market share, per automotive industry sales data
By December 2028, green hydrogen production costs fall below $3/kg in at least 5 major markets, per BloombergNEF hydrogen price tracking
Before January 2031, fossil fuel companies write down >$500 billion in stranded assets cumulatively since 2025, per company SEC filings and annual reports
By December 2028, solar and wind achieve grid parity (unsubsidized) in >20 major economies, per IRENA Global Energy Transformation report
Before January 2030, at least 5 climate adaptation projects demonstrate >15% annual ROI, per World Bank infrastructure project evaluations
By June 2029, green technology exports from leading countries (US, China, EU) exceed $500 billion annually, per WTO trade statistics
Before December 2030, battery storage costs fall below $50/kWh at utility scale, per BloombergNEF battery price survey
By January 2031, carbon pricing mechanisms cover >40% of global emissions with average price >$75/tonne CO2, per World Bank carbon pricing dashboard

scenarios.name: Fossil Lock-in
scenarios.description: Energy transition stalls due to political resistance and technological bottlenecks. Renewables grow slowly to only 35-40% by 2050 as fossil fuel infrastructure remains dominant. Climate investments fail to deliver returns, creating economic drag.

uncertainty_states.Energy Transition Speed: Slow transition: Renewables reach only 35-40% of global energy by 2050, dominated by continued fossil fuel dependence with high stranded asset costs and delayed infrastructure modernization.
uncertainty_states.Climate Investment Returns: Poor returns: Climate investments yield low productivity gains, green technologies remain expensive, and adaptation costs drain resources without generating economic benefits, reducing overall GDP growth.

key_drivers: Policy gridlock and fossil fuel lobbying
Climate adaptation costs without productivity gains
scenarios.why_exclusive: Cannot coexist with rapid renewable adoption or strong investment returns - represents world where both transition speed and investment efficiency remain low
signals: By December 2027, global renewable energy investment exceeds $2 trillion annually, per IEA World Energy Investment report
By December 2028, green hydrogen production costs fall below $3/kg in at least 5 major markets, per BloombergNEF hydrogen price tracking
By December 2028, solar and wind achieve grid parity (unsubsidized) in >20 major economies, per IRENA Global Energy Transformation report

scenarios.name: Muddle Through
scenarios.description: Moderate energy transition progresses with mixed investment results. Renewables reach 50-60% by 2050 through gradual policy support and cost reductions. Economic benefits are modest but steady.

uncertainty_states.Energy Transition Speed: Moderate transition: Renewables reach 50-60% with steady but unspectacular progress
uncertainty_states.Climate Investment Returns: Mixed returns: Some green technologies succeed while others underperform, creating moderate net economic benefits

key_drivers: Incremental policy progress without dramatic shifts
scenarios.why_exclusive: Represents moderate outcomes that cannot occur alongside either dramatic transition failure or breakthrough success scenarios
signals: By January 2029, at least 15 countries achieve >50% renewable electricity generation for full calendar year 2028, per national energy statistics
Before January 2030, at least 5 climate adaptation projects demonstrate >15% annual ROI, per World Bank infrastructure project evaluations
By June 2029, green technology exports from leading countries (US, China, EU) exceed $500 billion annually, per WTO trade statistics

scenarios.name: Efficient Transition
scenarios.description: Slow but highly efficient energy transition achieves 45-55% renewables by 2050 with exceptional investment returns. Technology breakthroughs and smart policy drive productivity gains despite measured transition pace.

uncertainty_states.Energy Transition Speed: Slow transition: Renewables reach only 35-40% of global energy by 2050, dominated by continued fossil fuel dependence with high stranded asset costs and delayed infrastructure modernization.
uncertainty_states.Climate Investment Returns: Strong returns: Climate technologies achieve breakthrough cost reductions, green infrastructure drives productivity gains, and early movers capture export advantages, boosting GDP through innovation and efficiency.

scenarios.why_exclusive: Cannot coexist with rapid transition scenarios due to measured pace, but achieves higher renewable share than other slow scenarios due to superior investment efficiency
signals: Before December 2030, battery storage costs fall below $50/kWh at utility scale, per BloombergNEF battery price survey
By January 2031, carbon pricing mechanisms cover >40% of global emissions with average price >$75/tonne CO2, per World Bank carbon pricing dashboard
Before January 2030, at least 5 climate adaptation projects demonstrate >15% annual ROI, per World Bank infrastructure project evaluations

scenarios.name: Green Revolution
scenarios.description: Rapid energy transition achieves 70-80% renewables by 2050 with strong investment returns. Breakthrough technologies and aggressive policies create a virtuous cycle of cost reductions and economic growth.

uncertainty_states.Energy Transition Speed: Rapid transition: Renewables achieve 70-80% of global energy by 2050, driving massive green infrastructure investment, energy cost reductions, and technological leadership advantages.
uncertainty_states.Climate Investment Returns: Strong returns: Climate technologies achieve breakthrough cost reductions, green infrastructure drives productivity gains, and early movers capture export advantages, boosting GDP through innovation and efficiency.

scenarios.why_exclusive: Cannot occur with slow transition or poor investment returns - requires both rapid adoption and strong economic performance from climate investments
signals: Before June 2030, Tesla or Chinese EV manufacturers achieve >20% global auto market share, per automotive industry sales data
Before January 2031, fossil fuel companies write down >$500 billion in stranded assets cumulatively since 2025, per company SEC filings and annual reports
By June 2029, green technology exports from leading countries (US, China, EU) exceed $500 billion annually, per WTO trade statistics
Before December 2030, battery storage costs fall below $50/kWh at utility scale, per BloombergNEF battery price survey

mece_reasoning: The four scenarios are mutually exclusive because they represent distinct combinations of transition speed and investment efficiency that cannot coexist. Fossil Lock-in requires both slow transition AND poor returns. Muddle Through represents moderate states that preclude extremes. Efficient Transition uniquely combines slow pace with high efficiency. Green Revolution requires both rapid transition AND strong returns. They are collectively exhaustive because they cover all logical combinations of the two key uncertainties, with renewable share ranges (35-40%, 45-55%, 50-60%, 70-80%) that span the full plausible outcome space from current ~15% to Paris targets of 60-70%, with no gaps or overlaps.
